data.title: SetData/GetData<T>
data.body:
When starting to fix #1455 I thought it might be a good idea to do parameter validation for GetData and SetData in a seperate method so we do the same checks in both, don't have duplicate code here and have a better overview of it. Maybe even abstract some of the checks up to Texture itself since this code can be shared for the most part and it'll make the checks consistent for all Texture types. 

I just realized the same methods exist for Vertex/IndexBuffers, not sure if we should share all around or just do textures. Thoughts on this?

Also, there are cases the checks miss because sizeof(T) was is always expected to be equal to 4 (which is expected to be the size of the format, but that isn't always the case either) and the size of T is not explicitly checked while in XNA it is. I'm happy to fix all this once we decide on the above paragraphs.

data.body:
Fixes #4824. Added the `Color(byte, byte, byte, byte)` constructor and made `Color(uint)` public. Also added some simple unit tests for the constructors and corrected a minor typo.

In the issue, there was some discussion about a separate `Color.FromBytes()` method, but I opted for another constructor overload, since the parameters must be `byte`s in either case. I did not add a `Color(byte, byte, byte)` overload with constant alpha to avoid excessive overloads - this is a more "advanced" overload after all. This can be changed if it makes the API cleaner, of course.

As expected, the new `byte` overload is clearly (40-60%) faster than the `int` version in a quick microbenchmark.

data.title: Pipeline automatic texture size reduction
data.body:
In some titles we've ported they are going from a console running at 1920x1080 with around 6GB of memory down to like a Vita which is basically half that resolution and much less GPU memory.  This is similar to having one game that targets PC and mobile where mobile sometimes requires smaller textures because of screen resolution and memory limits.

It would be good for the pipeline to support some feature that would automatically reduce texture sizes by 1 mip level before processing to account for these memory/resolution constrained devices.

In many games the majority of the textures would need this reduction with a few textures needing to opt-out of it.  Not sure how it would be presented to the user so that it is easy to setup.
- Is this a per-texture setting?
- Is this some global per-project setting?
- Is it maybe some mixture of both?

data.title: Support <Link> content in MGCB and Pipeline tool
data.body:
In XNA you could do the following in a content project:

```
    <Compile Include="..\..\..\art\gfx\wood.PNG">
      <Link>gfx\wood.PNG</Link>
      <Name>wood</Name>
      <Importer>TextureImporter</Importer>
      <Processor>TextureProcessor</Processor>
    </Compile>
```

With this the content pipeline reads the source content from the `..\..\..\art\gfx\wood.PNG` path then writes it out to `gfx\wood.PNG` in the output folder.

When importing this `.contentproj` into the Pipeline tool we get this:

```
#begin ../../../art/gfx/wood.PNG
/importer:TextureImporter
/processor:TextureProcessor
/build:../../../art/gfx/wood.PNG
```

This produces both the wrong output path when building content, but also looks wrong in the Pipeline tool which shows folders for `..` which it should never do.

There are multiple things to do to fix this:
1. Add support for links/rename of content on processing.
2. Correctly visualize these links in the Pipeline tool.
3. Support adding linked content in the Pipeline tool.
4. Support importing linked content from `.contentproj`.

This issue is similar to https://github.com/MonoGame/MonoGame/issues/4724, https://github.com/MonoGame/MonoGame/issues/4846, and https://github.com/MonoGame/MonoGame/issues/4980.

data.title: Better exception message when failing because of GraphicsProfile
data.body: There are a couple topics on the forum and at least one issue here (#5094) of games crashing with a "SharpDXException: The parameter is incorrect" in `CreatePixelShader()`. Often this is because the GraphicsProfile is set to Reach and SM4 is not supported then. If we can get the highest target shader model from the shader (can we do this?) and check it against the supported feature levels linked to the current GraphicsProfile we can throw an exception with a clear message before trying to let SharpDX create the shader and fail miserably.

data.title: Add IsConnected for Mouse and/or Keyboard
data.body:
This is just an Idea. 

Gamepad has a IsConnected method which we use to tell if the user has gamepads. 
Given we now support various platforms from Mobile to Console I thought it might be handy for the Keyboard and Mouse to have such a property. 

A used case for this.. 

A multi player game where on Desktop the users can either connect a Game pad or use the keyboard. During the game a message is shown on screen "Hit Button A to Join" or "Press Z Key to Join" depending on if a GamePad is detected or not. 

Now on a console you generally don't have keyboards.. So unless you #if code out it would be nice to have a way of knowing either

a) if a keyboard or mouse is present
b) Which "device" you are running on ... Mobile, Desktop, Console. 

I'm not sure how practical it is to detect a keyboard or mouse via the various API's we use in SDL/DirectX. I think they just assume its there and return no data if not.

So perhaps the solution is to have a "Mobile", "Desktop", "Console" enum.. 
but that has its own problems.. does UWP tell you which device type you are on.

Thoughts? @KonajuGames @tomspilman @cra0zy @mrhelmut

data.title: Fixed OpenAL CallingConvention on Function Pointers #5100
data.body:
The function pointers for OpenAL effects/filters were using
the platform default calling convention. On Mac and Linux
this is Cdecl, but on Windows it is StdCall.

OpenAL soft is built on windows using cdecl. As a result the
calls to these methods would either crash or produce unexpected
behaviour.

data.title: Fixed incorrect glyph position in FontDescriptionProcessor.cs
data.body:
Hi guys,

I believe I fixed a bug in the FontDescriptionProcessor.cs. 

line 120 original:
var cropping = new Rectangle(0, (int)(glyph.YOffset - yOffsetMin), (int)glyph.XAdvance, output.VerticalLineSpacing);

fixed:
var cropping = new Rectangle((int)(glyph.XAdvance + glyph.XOffset), (int)(glyph.YOffset - yOffsetMin), (int)glyph.XAdvance, output.VerticalLineSpacing);

In our case, using https://www.fontsquirrel.com/fonts/kingthings-petrock font, the 'c' character was positioned incorrectly. See the attached image.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1948647/17573784/973315ca-5f54-11e6-91a6-f44b5989403a.png)

Sorry I'm not submitting a PR, I'm not a git user.

data.title: SharpDX error when using texCUBElod / SampleLevel
data.body:
Every time when I use `texCUBElod(SamplerName, float4(SampleLocation, MipLevel))` or `TextureName.SampleLevel(SamplerName, SampleLocation, MipLevel)` and try to load an effect with `Content.Load<Effect>("Here/Goes/My/Fancy/Effect");` I get an error:

> An unhandled exception of type 'SharpDX.SharpDXException' occurred in SharpDX.dll
> Additional information: HRESULT: [0x80070057], Module: [General], ApiCode: [E_INVALIDARG/Invalid Arguments], Message: The parameter is incorrect.

Edit: 
Actually the same thing happens when I try to use `texCUBE(SamplerName, SampleLocation)` or `TextureName.Sample(SamplerName, SampleLocation)` under **vs_4_0**/**ps_4_0**. 
It works properly under vs_4_0_level_9_1/ps_4_0_level_9_1 and vs_4_0_level_9_3/ps_4_0_level_9_3.

PS. The effect compiles fine and the error occures during loading time.
